ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: live virtual lecture and virtual lab
Live virtual lecture + live virtual lab.
Virtual lab session with TA
The class consisted of a virtual coding lab with small groups of 2-3 students, and a weekly virtual live lecture.
Breakout rooms after lectures as the lab work section
Live virtual lab sessions lead by TA.
We had Zoom lectures and Zoom labs/breakout sessions.

For each lab section, we had a live virtual lecture before that was given by the professor. We then would be expected to apply the material learned in the lecture to our lab assignment with the help of the teaching fellows.
Live virtual lectures and virtual computing labs
There were both live virtual lectures, and a live lab. The lab was a zoom in breakout rooms with your lab groups. There was a TA in these labs that was available for answering questions.

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Python, data analysis, machine learning

Due to COVID-19, this year, PHYS 206L was revamped into a scientific computing and machine learning course in Python  a much more useful lab course for those interested in the theoretical and computational (rather than applied/experimental) domains of physics.

This course taught very useful skills for computational physics including python, Monte Carlo simlations, and machine learning techniques. These are all skills that are necessary for conducting modern physics research.
I learned a lot of python, as well as a deeper understanding of some of the theory behind certain numerical methods used in the sciences (physics and astronomy, specifically).
Python, machine learning methods, etc.
Intro to machine learning/training models and visualizing/evaluating the models.

This was a great introduction to python for scientific data analysis and manipulation. We covered things like monte carlo simulations to implementing machine learning algorithms. This courses gives you the foundation you need to use python for research and understand some of the issues and common errors which can arise. All around I think it is a great course for anyone looking to dip their toe into programing and learn some python for science applications.
I learned a lot of about Python coding, different physics computational problems, and different classifiers for artificial intelligence.
I learned the basics of programming in Python, and some basic data science and machine learning skills.

I gained a stronger understanding of using programming and data science tools and techniques to tackle problems in physics. The first half of the course focused on scientific computing methods, such as Simpson's Rule and Monte Carlo simulations, and their applications. It also introduced basic Python programming as Python was the language we used for all assignments. The second half of the course focused on basic machine learning and other data science techniques. The course focused more on exposure rather than completeness due to the issue of time, so most of what I learned was introductory. Nonetheless, the course had interesting assignments that effectively tested and cemented my understanding.

This class covers Python fundamentals, numerical differentiation and integration techniques, Monte Carlo methods, and concludes with an introduction to machine learning. The content is presented fairly quickly, with a good mixture of theory provided in lecture and application in the computing lab PSETs. By the end, we were proficient with various data science libraries (pandas, numpy, mathplotlib, sklearn) and could execute the knowledge mining process on real world problems (final project). Machine learning is presented as a powerful tool for scientific exploration with its limitations. The focus is on various classification models and their strengths and weaknesses, evaluation of models, and interpretation of results.
I learned a lot about different python coding packages and how to use them for physics research. I also learned a lot about machine learning.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Well done physics dept on this one -- a very solid lab course.

Strengths: The workload was well-suited for a half-credit course, as most of the assignments could be completed in class. The material covered also allowed for an expository survey into machine learning and its uses, which is good knowledge for any computational work one might encounter in the future. Prof Nagai was also happy to help, although his lectures did at times get somewhat repetitive, as he simply read aloud content on the slides.
Weaknesses: The first few weeks was an unsuccessful meet-in-the-middle attempt to introduce Python  way too fast-paced for beginners and a boring repetition of familiar material for others. This course would be much better off if it dived straight into the content and spent more time on more advanced simulation techniques and packages before spending the other half of the semester on machine learning.

Professor Daisuke was very open to suggestions for adapting the course to better suit student's needs. The lectures were engaging and there was a clear emphasis on how the material was useful for research. One of the few weaknesses of the course was simply the online format is hard to adjust to.

I think it was a mistake to say that no programming experience is required. The first few weeks were a waste of time for students already familiar with programming and later weeks were way too difficult for students without previous experience.
Perhaps more opportunities to practice coding (which could be optional) in addition to the problem sets could have been useful, but overall I thought the course was excellent.

Strength: Nice and helpful professor and TA
Weakness: Slightly boring

Strengths: virtual format translated perfectly for the subject matter, very relevant to modern scientific measurement and data handling.
Weaknesses: not many; honestly even as a brand-new coder I found the class straightforward-- as long as you put in the work to learn what you need to learn, you'll do great, which is personally how I think all classes should be.

Strengths: The lab session was really instructive and the TAs were great. Also for each lab you are put into a group which really helps foster collaboration and makes the problem solving more enjoyable. Furthermore, the workload was very manageable but still enough to make you feel like you knew the material well. Weakness: if you have no programming experience at all the lectures move quite fast and often I didn't understand how to implement concepts until the weekly lab. However the lecture slides are a great resource to refer to and as long as you ask the TAs for help you'll be fine.

Strength: Coding is fun! And the assignments were interesting, not too easy and not too hard, and fun to do. TAs were super great and helpful to talk to. Also it's broken up into two sessions which is better than having one super long session.
Weakness: Lecture a bit boring, can be just as helpful to read the slides independently.

I very much enjoyed this labI felt like what we learned was readily applicable to any kind of physics or science work I may do in the future and it will be incredibly useful to me later on. I also liked how we had the lecture time and then the lab time, as it broke up the time we spent sitting in front of the computer. The TA's were extremely helpful and approachable, so it was easy to ask questions and get assistance. However, I wish we could have gone more in depth; at times it felt like we glossed over topics because there is such a large volume of material we go over.

The instructor and teaching fellows were very effective in providing as much help as possible to the students. The material was also interesting and generally presented in an engaging format. The lectures could sometimes feel a bit long and drawn out due to a lack of activities or class discussions. The assignments were generally well-structured and effective in cementing understanding. However, a couple of assignments did feel short, making it hard to feel confident in the material the assignment covered.

An excellent introduction to modern computational techniques in science. Although the class was designed as a virtual lab to accommodate the constrains of this academic year, its content was exceedingly relevant (it should remain as a separate course since it fills a gap critical for physics majors). The depth in which numerical integration and differentiation were explored is a clear strength of this class. I enjoyed exploring what improvements could be made to the algorithms and feel like I have a thorough understanding of how they work. The PSETs were the proper difficulty as to be challenging yet rewarding, with cool connections to higher level physics. The machine learning component of the class was a great overview for beginners. Professor Nagai is super knowledgeable and enthusiastic! He breathes this subject and will make you spontaneously smile as you zoom through the lecture.
The vast range in background each student brings to this class is the largest challenge. Personally, I enjoyed the selection of content and found the lectures to move very quickly (in his excitement, Professor Nagai can really click through the slides). We needed a lot more time for the in-class exercises. It helped me to review and take notes on the lectures after class. However, one of my lab partners had not worked with Python before and was rightfully overwhelmed when we covered nearly all of it in the first three weeks. I would recommend getting comfortable with Python basics (data types, control structures, functions, etc.) before this class starts; it is not really an "introduction". On the other hand, some students were very good programmers and wanted to see more of machine learning and harder exercises. To improve the class for everyone, I would offer some resources in the syllabus for students less comfortable with Python to work through before the class and extra optional exercises for the experienced (this was a good feature added toward the end of the semester).

Strengths: Engaging lectures, very reasonable workload, nice to stay with one lab group the whole semester.

Improvements: The problem sets could be worded in more clear ways.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Virtual lab was great and splitting into both a lecture and lab was a prime move.

This computational lab was well-suited for learning during the pandemic, as it was not hampered by the lack of an in-person component. Furthermore, the use of Google Colab Python notebooks aided significantly with collaboration among peers in the course.

The split of the course into lecture and programming TF sessions was very good. Also having programming exercises during the lecture was a great idea. Improvements could be made if students were able to engage together more often rather than only with one lab partner.
The virtual aspect of the course did not hinder it in any way. Using Google CoLab was efficient and user-friendly, and the breakout room nature of the labs was perfect for simulating a real-life lab.
Successes include the availability of the professors and TA among the Slack channel also.
I really thought the switch to python was WAY. more relevant to my major (BME) than the traditional version of the course.

Since this course was all coding, the format was great for the COVID pandemic. Collaboration was easy due to using resources like google colab and the share screen functionality of zoom. Overall this is a great alternative to an in person lab and gives you a solid coding foundation for future scientific research.
Having a Slack was great for questions. Break out sessions were great because I became friends with my peeps.

I really liked the format of the lecture and then lab timeit was nice to listen and take notes on the topic and then apply them in lab time to a problem set. I also liked the exercises we had during lecture, because it broke up the rhythm of the presentation and allowed us to experiment with what we had just learned.

I found the lectures to be generally engaging and interesting with the activities and discussions that were included. However, I think the lectures could be improved by using breakout rooms to facilitate more participation from students. This would especially help if the class size remained as large as it was this past semester.

Designed specifically for remote learning conditions this year, this course was very well adapted to the online environment. The live virtual lectures and the online computing labs were engaging and kept the class moving at a good clip. I do not see much to improve in the format of the class.

Success: using breakout rooms for the lab, well made virtual lectures

Could be improved: hard to stare at the screen for the entirety of lecture and then the lab. There was occasionally a short break during lecture, which was super helpful. It would be nice to have this more consistently.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Highly. This is a gem and I'm glad the dept reorganized Phys 206L into this for our virtual semester. Wayyyy better than Phys 205L.

This course might be revamped into another physics department elective, in which case it is most definitely worth taking. It teaches valuable tools that will come in handy in any form of computational research, and is definitely a valuable addition to the coursework of any physics-related major.
Yes, I would highly recommend this course to anyone interested in physics research. You will learn very useful skills that you can then later apply.

Absolutely! For those who have little or no python experience, the learning curve at the beginning is a bit steep, but by about the fourth lab I would say most students were running on a similar level. If you have some python experience, the class is still helpful as an introduction to certain methods such as Monte-Carlo simulations and machine learning techniques, which are still very important skills for research in the sciences.
If you're taking it, you need it for the major. Otherwise, not really.

Yes, the python version was much improved. I took 206 in the spring of last sem and had to drop because it was too much to write such long lab reports.  This was MUCH more reasonable in terms of workload for a 0.5 level course.

I would recommend this course to any student who wants a broad and functional introduction to scientific programing. Python is a great first language to learn and this course introduces you to a lot of advanced topics in a really accessible way. This is a great option for students who only need to learn to program for research and other purposes. However I wouldn't recommend this course as an introduction to CS. The skills gained in this course are very practical and application based and thus doesn't cover a lot of the typical base skills for CS.
Yes I would! Def the best physics class I've taken and perfect for a virtual format!!!

I would definitely recommend this course to another student who has to take it for their major. I learned a lot of basic concepts in Python programming for physics, so it was a great introduction to data science and machine learning topics. This is not really a substitute for a computer science class, however, and it felt like the vast majority of the students in this class had already learned how to program and had experience with data science and machine learning. Regardless, the work felt useful and meaningful, and the tasks not overwhelming at all, as compared with other lab courses I have taken.

I think that the relatively low workload and interesting material covered make this course recommendable to other students. It does not demand a lot of working knowledge about physics, programming, or data science, which makes it even more accessible to non-STEM students. The assignments were not incredibly challenging and both the professor and teaching fellows were always eager to help in any way they could.

YES, this class is essential to the modern physicist! Numerical methods and machine learning techniques are important tools used in research and across higher science. I truly learned some much this semester. This class really needs to become permanent. Also, Professor Nagai is amazing and definitely the one to take this class with! His excitement permeates the lectures and is contagious. The only caveat is that you should be comfortable with the basics of Python before the class starts; otherwise, you will have to scramble through the first couple weeks to which all basic programming is compressed.
Yes, I would strongly recommend this course to another student. It was very helpful for improving my coding skills and machine learning knowledge.
